channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Censored in China: ‘Today,’ ‘Tonight’ and ‘Big Yellow Duck’
item.description: The words “today,” “tonight” and “big yellow duck” are all banned on China’s popular Weibo, or microblog, as the state tries to ensure political calm on June 4, the 24th anniversary of the crushing of the 1989 democracy protests.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A Chinese man blocked a line of tanks heading east on Chang'an Avenue near Tiananmen Square in Beijing on June 5, 1989.

item.title: Viktor Kulikov Dies at 91; Led Warsaw Pact Forces
item.description: Marshal Kulikov resisted efforts to slow the arms race and pressed Poland to squash the Solidarity protest movement.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN
item.media:description: Marshal Viktor Kulikov reviewing troops in Hungary in 1979.

item.title: Israeli Start-Up Gives Visually Impaired a Way to Read
item.description: A company has developed a camera-based system intended to give the visually impaired the ability to both “read” easily and move freely.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN MARKOFF
item.media:description: Liat Negrin, an employee at OrCam, wears a device made by the company that consists of a camera and a small computer.

item.title: Polio Virus Discovered in Sewage From Israel
item.description: The discovery of the virus was the first in the country since 2002, the World Health Organization said, but no newly paralyzed children or adults have been identified.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: Statements by Detained Egyptian Terrorism Suspect Are Focus of Sentencing
item.description: The accounts of an Egyptian who lawyers said had most likely been tortured were unreliable, the defense counsel of a former Brooklyn man said.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: The Lede: Add Tear Gas and Stir: Images of Police Brutality Fuel Anger in Turkey
item.description: Frustrated by the relatively sparse coverage of recent demonstrations in the Turkish media, supporters of the protest movement have turned to social networks to share images of police officers using force.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Hamdallah, Palestinian Authority’s Premier, Is Admired
item.description: Rami Hamdallah, 54, a respected academician who lacks political experience and an international profile, is known for his work expanding his university.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Rami Hamdallah, an academic without a political record, is known for his compassion.

item.title: China’s New Leadership Has Ties to Tiananmen Era
item.description: The immersion of today’s leaders of China in the political experimentation that preceded the Tiananmen Square crackdown in 1989 raises the question of whether they will be open to new ideas and discussion.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Student protesters faced police officers in Tiananmen Square in April 1989 while grieving for Hu Yaobang, a former Communist Party leader and liberal whose death set off the protests.

item.title: Turkish Protests Raise Questions on Leader’s Rule
item.description: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan is facing his worst political crisis in more than a decade of power, and he seems little inclined to change his approach.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Ed Ou for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators ran from tear gas fired by the police during a clash in Istanbul on Monday. Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan is facing a political crisis.

item.title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
item.description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,213 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Trial Portrays Two Sides Private in WikiLeaks Case
item.description: During a court-martial on Monday, a prosecutor said Pfc. Bradley Manning put sensitive information into enemy hands, while his defense lawyer said his client had been “naïve.”
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.media:description: Pfc. Bradley Manning at Fort Meade, Md., in May.

item.title: U.S. Adds to Its List of Sanctions Against Iran
item.description: President Obama authorized sanctions on any foreign financial institution that conducts “significant transactions” in the Iranian rial, the currency of Iran.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Activist Sentenced to Prison for Insulting Morsi
item.description: An Egyptian court sentenced an activist to six months in prison on Monday on charges that he insulted President Mohamed Morsi and circulated false news on television.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: State Department Offers Rewards for Terrorist Leaders
item.description: The State Department announced that it was offering rewards for information leading to the location of the leaders of Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: Kabul Journal: A Youthful Corps Whose Esprit Comes From Hustle
item.description: A band of children is planting outside the headquarters of the coalition forces in Afghanistan, selling scarves, hats and books almost every day, except when they are kicked out by the police.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Children outside the military headquarters of the coalition forces. In a way, the young peddlers are an elite group, with access to a steady stream of Westerners

item.title: Roma Still Shunned in France Ahead of E.U. Rules Change
item.description: Life hasn’t gotten any easier for immigrants from Romania and Bulgaria under the Socialist government of President François Hollande.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Shifting Cargo May Have Doomed Plane That Crashed Near Kabul
item.description: Afghan investigators said quickly shifting cargo of heavy military vehicles contributed to the crash of a civilian cargo plane on April 29 in which all seven people aboard were killed.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED and MATTHEW L. WALD

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: China’s Development a ‘Threat’ to Democracies, Authors Say
item.description: As China buys strategic assets around the world and flexes its commercial muscle, will Western countries increasingly have to play by Beijing’s statist rules? Do these threaten democracies?
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Kerry Says U.S. Came ‘Late’ to Syria Peace Effort
item.description: The remarks by Secretary of State John Kerry carried the implication that the Obama administration had moved too slowly in its first term on the Syria crisis.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS and ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: British Leaders Tackle Radicalization After Killing
item.description: Two suspects in a soldier’s death made separate court appearances as politicians met to seek ways of thwarting what the government has called the “poisonous narrative” of militant Islamic radicalization.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS and ALAN COWELL

item.title: Global Health: Plastic Bags to Keep Premature Babies Warm
item.description: In poor countries, simple plastic bags are an alternative to the sterile plastic wrap used to regulate the body temperature of very premature babies in the United States, a study suggests.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. M cNEIL J r.

item.title: The Lede: Floods Sweep Through Central Europe
item.description: Heavy rains led to the evacuation of tens and thousands in parts of the Czech Republic, Austria and Germany, and at least seven people were reported killed.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: The Lede: Daughter of Michigan Woman Killed in Syria Wants Body Returned to U.S.
item.description: Friends and family of Nicole Lynn Mansfield struggle to understand how she became caught in a gun battle with Syrian government forces.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER PRESTON

item.title: Seven Die in Iran After Drinking Homemade Alcohol
item.description: A batch of illegally distilled alcohol has killed seven people, hospitalized dozens and blinded several others in the southern city of Rafsanjan.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Jordan Blocks Local Access to 300 News Web Sites
item.description: The sites were blocked inside the country under a law that was enacted in September as opposition to King Abdullah II grew more outspoken.
item.dc:creator: By RANA F. SWEIS and JODI RUDOREN
